title: 106_hr2572
content: The Act may be cited as the "Apollo Exploration Award Act of 2000". Congress findings include the first humans landing on the moon in 1969 during the Apollo 11 mission, followed by ten other Americans exploring the lunar surface between 1969 and 1972. The Apollo lunar landing missions were successful due to the pioneering work of previous Apollo missions, including Apollo 7 and Apollo 8. Apollo 13 safely returned from the Moon after an explosion disabled their command module in April 1970. In January 1967, astronauts Virgil I. Grissom, Edward H. White, and Roger B. Chaffee tragically lost their lives in a fire during a spacecraft test for the first manned Apollo mission. Since the Apollo program, astronauts have shared their experiences to inspire space exploration and human achievement. Several astronauts, including Ronald E. Evans, James B. Irwin, Stuart A. Roosa, Alan B. Shepard Jr., and Charles J. "Pete" Conrad Jr., have passed away after completing their missions. The Congress acknowledges the bravery and achievements of Apollo program astronauts and proposes an Apollo Exploration Award. The Administrator of NASA will create the "Apollo Exploration Award" to honor Apollo astronauts with a lunar rock sample as the central feature. Awards will be presented to astronauts or their family members. The Administrator of NASA will create the "Apollo Exploration Award" to honor Apollo astronauts with a lunar rock sample. Recipients include Buzz Aldrin, William Anders, Neil Armstrong, Alan Bean, Frank Borman, Eugene Cernan, Roger Chaffee, Michael Collins, Charles Conrad Jr., R. Walter Cunningham, Charles Duke Jr., Donn Eisele, Ronald Evans, Richard Gordon Jr., Virgil Grissom, Fred Haise Jr., James Irwin, and James Lovell Jr. The Apollo Exploration Award will honor Apollo astronauts with a lunar rock sample. Recipients include James A. Lovell Jr., Thomas K. Mattingly II, James A. McDivitt, Edgar D. Mitchell, Stuart A. Roosa, Walter M. Schirra Jr., Harrison H. Schmitt, Russell L. Schweickart, David R. Scott, Alan B. Shepard Jr., Thomas P. Stafford, John L. Swigert Jr., Edward H. White, Alfred M. Worden, and John W. Young. The Act prohibits using the award for profit and restricts its transfer except to family members or for public display. Ownership reverts to the Administrator if not inherited or displayed publicly. SEC. 7 of the Act allows the Administrator to recall lunar samples for scientific purposes and replace them if necessary. The recalled samples must be promptly returned to their owner.
